SPECIALITY: Cardiothoracic Surgery - Cardiothoracic surgery is a surgical subspecialty focused on operating on organs within the chest, primarily the heart, lungs, and esophagus.
SET DISCRIPTION: These instruments are used for accessing and manipulating the heart, lungs, and other chest organs during procedures.
NAME: Artery Forceps Curved 6"
BRIEF: It is a surgical instrument, also called a hemostat, used to clamp and control blood flow by grasping and compressing blood vessels during medical, veterinary, and laboratory procedures
DESCRIPTION:
Structure: An artery forceps consists of two arms that come together to form jaws, designed to grasp and hold tissue or blood vessels. 
Jaws: The jaws are typically serrated, meaning they have ridges that provide a firm, secure grip. Some may also have teeth for extra security. 
Handle: The handle provides a grip for the user to operate the forceps. 
Locking mechanism: Many artery forceps feature a ratchet mechanism that keeps the jaws locked closed once applied, allowing for hands-free hemostasis.
TYPE:
Straight Forceps: These have straight jaws, used for clamping vessels and tissues in easily accessible areas. 
Curved Forceps: With curved jaws, these provide better maneuverability and access to blood vessels in confined or hard-to-reach spaces.
USAGE:
Hemostasis: The primary use is to clamp arteries and veins to control bleeding during surgery, maintaining a clear surgical field. 
Grasping Tissues: They can also be used to grasp and manipulate tissues, sutures, and other prosthetic materials. 
Ligation: After clamping a vessel, the forceps hold it in place for ligation (tying it off), which permanently stops blood flow. 
Dissection: Some forceps, like Adson forceps, are used for delicate dissection and to provide a clear view of the surgical site
IMPORTANT CONSIDERATIONS:
Tissue Damage: As forceps are crushing instruments, proper technique and appropriate forceps size are crucial to avoid damaging delicate tissues. 
Application: The choice between straight or curved forceps, and their size, depends on the location and type of structure being addressed.
CLEANING & STERILIZATION:
Pre-cleaning: Clean the instrument immediately after use to prevent the drying of biological matter. 
Solution: Use a neutral pH (pH 7) cleaning solution for manual or ultrasonic cleaning. 
Process: Clean the retractor in its open position to ensure thorough and effective cleaning of all parts. 
Tools: Use soft cloths, soft plastic brushes made of nylon, or water spray guns for cleaning. 
Drying: Dry instruments completely before sterilization or storage to prevent rust and microbial growth
INSPECTION & MAINTENANCE:
Lubrication 
Frequency: Lubricate the movable and jointed parts of the retractor once a month.
Lubricant: Use a high-quality, surgical-grade instrument lubricant; do not use industrial oils.
Application: Ensure the lubricant reaches all moving parts for smooth operation and to prevent seizing.
Storage 
Environment: Store surgical instruments in a dry, clean environment.
Protection: Seal away instruments to prevent exposure to moisture, which can lead to oxidation and rust.
Inspection: Before use, visually inspect the retractor for any signs of corrosion, damage, or wear.

NAME: Dissecting Forceps Toothed 6"/ 8"
BRIEF: It is a 6" or 8" surgical instrument made of stainless steel with serrated, toothed tips designed to provide a secure grip for manipulating delicate tissues in medical and laboratory procedures. Its primary usage is to grasp and hold slippery or fatty tissues during various surgeries (such as general, orthopedic, and plastic surgery), dissections, and other tasks requiring a firm, non-slip hold, though its teeth can cause minor tissue damage.
DESCRIPTION:
Size: The "6"" indicates the length of the forceps, measuring approximately 6 inches (15 cm). 
Material: They are typically constructed from high-grade stainless steel for durability, corrosion resistance, and easy sterilization. 
Toothed Jaws: The most distinguishing feature is the finely serrated or toothed surface on the inside of the jaws, providing a firm grip on tissues. 
Body: They have a slender, straight body with finger holes for comfortable handling. 
Joint: A box joint or ratchet mechanism at the handles allows for controlled clamping force.
USAGE:
Tissues with a firm grip: The toothed tips are ideal for holding tissues that are slippery or require a more secure hold, such as skin, fascia, or abdominal wall tissue, according to Andersen Caledonia. 
Delicate manipulation: They are used to grasp, retract, and manipulate small or delicate structures during surgical procedures in various specialties, including: 
General Surgery: For manipulating soft tissues.
Plastic Surgery: In reconstructive procedures.
Orthopedic Surgery: For dissections in joint and bone procedures.
Otolaryngology (ENT): For handling tissues in the ear, nose, and throat.
Dissections: Used in anatomical and biological dissections in laboratory and educational settings to hold specimens securely. 
Comparison to smooth forceps: Non-toothed (smooth) forceps are preferred when minimal tissue disruption is essential, whereas toothed forceps offer a more secure but potentially more traumatic grip

NAME: Mayo Scissors , Straight 7"
BRIEF: Straight Mayo scissors are versatile surgical instruments with strong, semi-blunt, straight blades, designed for cutting superficial tissues, sutures, dressing, and steri-strips. They are also known as "suture scissors" due to their primary use in cutting sutures, but can also be used for dissecting delicate tissues near the surface of a wound.
DESCRIPTION:
Straight Blades: Unlike their curved counterparts, straight Mayo scissors feature blades that follow a straight path, offering precise control for surface-level cuts. 
Semi-Blunt Ends: They have semi-blunt tips, a feature that distinguishes them from other surgical scissors and helps minimize tissue damage during use. 
Strong Blades and Handles: Mayo scissors are known for their strong construction, allowing them to cut tougher materials like meshes and rubber, in addition to delicate tissues. 
Versatility: These scissors are versatile, used for a range of tasks from cutting sutures to dissecting ligaments and fascia.
USAGE:
Cutting Superficial Tissues: Their straight design is ideal for cutting tissues or structures located on the surface of a wound. 
Suture and Dressing Removal: They are frequently used for cutting sutures and removing dressing materials or steri-strips from the skin. 
Ligature and Fascia Cutting: Straight Mayo scissors are suitable for cutting ligatures, fascia, tendons, and ligaments. 
Dissection of Delicate Tissues: In some applications, they can also be used for the dissection of delicate tissues near the body's surface. 
General Utility: Often referred to as "utility scissors" in a medical setting, they serve as a handy tool for various needs in surgery and other procedures
CLEANING & STERILIZATION:
Pre-cleaning: Clean the instrument immediately after use to prevent the drying of biological matter. 
Solution: Use a neutral pH (pH 7) cleaning solution for manual or ultrasonic cleaning. 
Process: Clean the retractor in its open position to ensure thorough and effective cleaning of all parts. 
Tools: Use soft cloths, soft plastic brushes made of nylon, or water spray guns for cleaning. 
Drying: Dry instruments completely before sterilization or storage to prevent rust and microbial growth
INSPECTION & MAINTENANCE:
Lubrication 
Frequency: Lubricate the movable and jointed parts of the retractor once a month.
Lubricant: Use a high-quality, surgical-grade instrument lubricant; do not use industrial oils.
Application: Ensure the lubricant reaches all moving parts for smooth operation and to prevent seizing.
Storage 
Environment: Store surgical instruments in a dry, clean environment.
Protection: Seal away instruments to prevent exposure to moisture, which can lead to oxidation and rust.
Inspection: Before use, visually inspect the retractor for any signs of corrosion, damage, or wear.

NAME: Backhaus Towel Clip 5"
BRIEF: A 5" Backhaus Towel Clip, also known as a Backhaus Towel Clamp, is a surgical instrument with sharp, inwardly-curved, perforating prongs and a scissor-like handle with a ratchet locking system. It is primarily used to firmly secure surgical drapes and towels to a patient's skin to define the surgical field and prevent movement during a procedure. The clamp's sharp prongs grip the drapes and skin, while the ratchet ensures a stable hold, and its stainless steel construction allows for repeated sterilization and reuse.
DESCRIPTION:
Design: The instrument has a scissor-like construction with two finger rings for easy handling and a boxlock system for smooth joint movement. 
Prongs: It features 1x1 prongs designed to perforate and provide a firm grip on both the drapes and the patient's underlying skin. 
Locking Mechanism: A ratchet locking mechanism provides a secure hold, preventing the clamp from slipping or shifting during surgery. 
Material: Constructed from high-grade stainless steel, it is durable, corrosion-resistant, and suitable for multiple sterilization cycles (autoclavable). 
Size: The 5-inch (or approximately 12.7 cm) size is a common length, catering to various surgical needs.
USAGE:
Securing Drapes: The primary use is to attach sterile drapes to a patient's skin at the edges of the operative site, thus establishing and maintaining the surgical field. 
Preventing Movement: By gripping the drapes and skin, it keeps them from shifting or slipping, ensuring the surgeon has a clear view of the surgical site. 
Tissue Grasping: The clamp's strong grip also makes it useful for grasping tissue during minor surgical interventions. 
Bone Fracture Management: It can be used to hold, secure, and gently reduce small bone fractures in orthopedic procedures.

NAME: Yaunker Suction Tip Adult
BRIEF: An Adult Yankauer Suction Tip is a rigid, plastic, medical instrument with a large, bulbous tip and a wide opening, designed to suction large volumes of fluids, blood, and secretions from the oropharynx and operative sites without damaging surrounding tissues. Its primary uses include removing secretions that could lead to aspiration, clearing surgical fields during procedures, and controlling oral secretions in patients unable to clear them themselves.
DESCRIPTION:
Material: Typically made of rigid plastic. 
Design: Features a large, bulbous head and a wide opening to allow for effective suctioning of large amounts of fluid and debris. 
Rigidity: Its rigid nature provides control and prevents it from collapsing during use. 
Variations: Available with or without a thumb control vent to regulate suction.
USAGE:
Oropharyngeal Suctioning: Used to remove secretions from the mouth and throat, preventing aspiration. 
Surgical Suction: Clears blood, fluids, and debris from surgical sites, improving visibility for the surgical team. 
Oral Hygiene: Helps patients who have difficulty clearing their mouths, such as those with swallowing impairments (dysphagia), to maintain oral health. 
Emergency Medicine: In emergencies, it's used to control airway secretions, fresh blood, or vomitus to assist with procedures like endotracheal intubation.

NAME: Micro Suction Tip With Thumb Control , No.3
BRIEF: A micro suction tip with thumb control is a surgical instrument, often used in ENT procedures, that allows a medical professional to precisely control the suction intensity by using a thumb-activated valve to cover or uncover holes on the instrument's handle. This feature is crucial for safely and effectively removing fluids like blood and mucus, or debris like plaque, from delicate tissues and providing a clear field of vision for the surgeon.
DESCRIPTION:
Instrument Type: A specialized adapter or tip designed for microscopic or endoscopic suction procedures. 
Material: Made from high-quality, durable materials such as stainless steel, making it corrosion-resistant, autoclavable, and suitable for repeated use. 
Thumb Control Valve: An integrated mechanism on the handle that allows the user to regulate the suction pressure by sliding their thumb over strategically placed holes. 
Ergonomics: Designed for ease of handling and to reduce the risk of blockages with its streamlined and smooth internal bore. 
Compatibility: Compatible with standard suction tubing and other surgical tips, ensuring a secure and leak-proof fit.
USAGE:
Controlled Suction: The primary function is to provide precise and controlled suction during medical procedures. 
ENT Procedures: Widely used in Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT) surgeries for procedures like myringotomy, nasal surgeries, sinus procedures, and tonsillectomies. 
Oral Care: Also used for cleaning the mouth by removing food, plaque, and other secretions, especially in patients who have difficulty spitting. 
Airway Management: Essential for maintaining a clear airway by removing excess secretions, blood, or other materials that could obstruct the patient's breathing. 
Enhanced Visualization: By keeping the operative field clear of fluids, it significantly improves the surgeon's visualization and precision during microscopic surgeries. 
Minimizing Tissue Trauma: The ability to instantly adjust suction intensity helps prevent damage to delicate tissues in areas like the nasal cavity or middle ear.

NAME: Cardiotomy Sucker, Adult
BRIEF: A cardiotomy suction cannula is a medical device used during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) to remove blood from the surgical site and return it to the heart-lung machine. It is an essential component of the CPB circuit during open-heart surgeries, such as coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
USAGE:
The cardiotomy suction cannula performs this function:
It is connected to a vacuum source and a cardiotomy reservoir, a component of the CPB circuit.
The surgeon uses the cannula to suction shed blood and debris directly from the surgical field.
The collected blood is channeled into the cardiotomy reservoir, where it is defoamed and filtered to remove air and debris.
Finally, the processed blood is returned to the patient's circulation via the heart-lung machine.

NAME: Czerny Retractor  Double Ended     Also called as Double hook retractor
BRIEF: A double-ended Czerny retractor is a surgical instrument with two different working endsone with prongs and the other with a flat bladeused to hold back tissues during surgical procedures, providing a clear view of the surgical site. It is made from stainless steel, is reusable and autoclavable, and its central handle may feature a fenestration to aid in visualizing and cauterizing bleeders. It is commonly used in general surgery, particularly for hernia repair, laparotomies, and during surgical closures.
DESCRIPTION:
Double-Ended Design: The defining feature is the two different types of working ends on a single instrument. 
Pronged End: One end typically has a pronged or rake-style design to grasp and retract soft tissues. 
Flat Blade End: The other end features a flat blade, often broader, used for retracting tissues or to provide an unobstructed view of the surgical field. 
Handle: The handle is designed for a comfortable and firm grip, providing control to the surgeon. Some models have a central oval fenestration (hole). 
Material: Czerny retractors are made from surgical-grade stainless steel, which is durable, corrosion-resistant, and suitable for sterilization and reuse. 
S-Shaped Design: Some models are described as S-shaped, allowing for better maneuverability in various surgical contexts.
USAGE:
Soft Tissue Retraction: The primary use is to gently hold back soft tissues, muscles, or organs to expose the deeper structures and organs of the surgical site. 
General Surgical Procedures: It is especially useful in procedures like hernia repair and laparotomies to ensure the surgeon has adequate visibility. 
Surgical Closure: The retractor is particularly helpful during the closing phase of a surgery, allowing surgeons to see and manage any bleeders in the underlying tissues. 
Versatility: The dual-ended nature provides flexibility, allowing the surgeon to switch between the pronged and flat blade ends as needed during the procedure. 
Specialized Procedures: Beyond general surgery, it's employed in specialties such as gynecology, urology, ENT, and even plastic surgery.

The term "any size" refers to the availability of these retractors in different lengths and blade dimensions to suit the specific needs and depths of various surgical incisions and procedures.
DESCRIPTION:

NAME: Mastoid (Mollison) Self  Retaining  Retractor  Curved  8"
BRIEF: Mollison self-retaining mastoid retractor is a specialized tool that assists surgeons in broadening the incision site for surgical manipulation in different surgical practices.
DESCRIPTION:
While designs can vary, a typical mastoid self-retaining retractor includes: 
Handle: The main body of the instrument, which the surgeon grips. Some designs feature finger rings for better control.
Blades (or arms): Curved shafts leading from the handle to the prongs. The curve helps the instrument conform to the area behind the ear.
Prongs: Situated at the tips of the blades, these hooks gently grip the edges of the incision. They come in various configurations, such as sharp or blunt, and a variety of prong counts, like 3x3 or 4x4.
Ratchet (or lock): This mechanism allows the surgeon to control the degree of retraction and lock the instrument in place
USAGE: Its self-locking mechanism holds back soft tissue, such as skin and muscle, allowing the surgeon to operate with both hands free

NAME: Morse Sternal Retractor
BRIEF: The Morse sternal retractor is a specialized surgical instrument used to retract the sternum, or breastbone, during open-chest procedures. It is available in various sizes to accommodate different patient anatomies, from infants to adults.
DESCRIPTION:
Function: The primary function of the retractor is to hold the sternum open, providing the surgeon with a clear and wide field of view to the chest cavity, heart, lungs, and major blood vessels.
Design: It typically consists of a ratchet bar, a fixed arm, and a movable arm with a rotational handle for controlled spreading.
Blades: Many designs feature four movable blades. The angled blades can adapt to the contour of the ribs, and small lateral blades minimize tissue damage.
Material: Morse sternal retractors are crafted from premium-grade stainless steel for its durability, corrosion resistance, and ability to be repeatedly sterilized
USAGE:

Infant: For the smallest patients, with corresponding blade dimensions.
Child: For pediatric cardiac and thoracic procedures.
Adult (Medium and Large): The most common sizes, with larger blades and a wider spread for adult patients. For example, an adult-large size may offer up to 205 mm of spread

NAME: Shall Cross Clamp Curved 7"
BRIEF: Refers to a Shallcross Cystic Duct Forceps, which are often curved and around 7 inches in length. It is a surgical instrument used to grasp and clamp tissue in the depth during medical procedures.
USAGE: These are used in gallbladder and bile duct procedures, and a 7-inch, curved version is available.
CLEANING & STERILIZATION:
Pre-cleaning: Clean the retractor immediately after use to prevent the drying of biological matter. 
Solution: Use a neutral pH (pH 7) cleaning solution for manual or ultrasonic cleaning. 
Process: Clean the retractor in its open position to ensure thorough and effective cleaning of all parts. 
Tools: Use soft cloths, soft plastic brushes made of nylon, or water spray guns for cleaning. 
Drying: Dry instruments completely before sterilization or storage to prevent rust and microbial growth
INSPECTION & MAINTENANCE:
Lubrication 
Frequency: Lubricate the movable and jointed parts of the retractor once a month.
Lubricant: Use a high-quality, surgical-grade instrument lubricant; do not use industrial oils.
Application: Ensure the lubricant reaches all moving parts for smooth operation and to prevent seizing.
Storage 
Environment: Store surgical instruments in a dry, clean environment.
Protection: Seal away instruments to prevent exposure to moisture, which can lead to oxidation and rust.
Inspection: Before use, visually inspect the retractor for any signs of corrosion, damage, or wear.

NAME: Mayo Heggar Needle Holder 7"
BRIEF: Mayo-Hegar needle holder is a versatile surgical instrument used to grasp and manipulate medium-to-large-sized suture needles during surgical procedures. Its design, which features a heavy, tapered jaw, a self-locking ratchet, and finger-rings, makes it a reliable tool for wound closure and tissue repair in various medical fields.
DESCRIPTION:
Jaws: It has broad, cross-serrated jaws with a rounded tip, which provides a firm and secure, slip-resistant grip on the needle.
Tungsten carbide inserts: Many high-quality Mayo-Hegar holders have tungsten carbide (TC) inserts on the jaws for enhanced durability and a firmer, longer-lasting grip. These instruments are often identified by gold-plated finger rings.
Ratchet mechanism: The self-locking ratchet holds the needle securely without requiring continuous hand pressure, which helps to reduce hand fatigue for the surgeon.
Finger rings: The large finger-ring handles are designed to be comfortable and provide excellent control.
Material: It is typically made from high-grade, rust-resistant stainless steel that can withstand repeated autoclave sterilization.
Sizes: Mayo-Hegar needle holders are available in a range of lengths, from 5 to 12 inches and longer, to accommodate different surgical needs, such as reaching deeper tissue.
USAGE:
General surgery: It is widely used for wound closure and general suturing procedures.
Orthopedic surgery: The instrument's strength and grip make it suitable for suturing muscle and fascia in orthopedic cases.
Obstetrics and gynecology: Surgeons use it for procedures such as C-sections and other tissue repairs.
Dental surgery: It is employed in oral surgeries and implant procedures.
Veterinary medicine: Its robust design makes it a common tool in animal surgery
IMPORTANT CONSIDERATIONS:
Advantages
Strong and secure grip: The cross-serrated jaws and durable construction provide a reliable grip, preventing the needle from slipping or rotating during suturing.
Versatility: The Mayo-Hegar is a multi-purpose tool that can be used for a variety of surgical applications involving medium and large needles, and can even be used for tissue handling.
Durability: The use of high-quality stainless steel and tungsten carbide inserts (in premium models) ensures a long service life. 
Disadvantages
Potential for needle damage: The hard tungsten carbide inserts may increase the likelihood of bending or breaking very fine needles, or weakening suture material, if not used carefully.
Not for delicate work: For very fine sutures or delicate microsurgeries, other instruments like the Castroviejo or Olsen-Hegar needle holders are often preferred due to their finer tips.
Requires practice: Holding and manipulating the needle holder with precision can be challenging, and some grips, like "palming," are harder for left-handed surgeons to use.
CLEANING & STERILIZATION:
Pre-cleaning: Clean the retractor immediately after use to prevent the drying of biological matter. 
Solution: Use a neutral pH (pH 7) cleaning solution for manual or ultrasonic cleaning. 
Process: Clean the retractor in its open position to ensure thorough and effective cleaning of all parts. 
Tools: Use soft cloths, soft plastic brushes made of nylon, or water spray guns for cleaning. 
Drying: Dry instruments completely before sterilization or storage to prevent rust and microbial growth
INSPECTION & MAINTENANCE:
Lubrication 
Frequency: Lubricate the movable and jointed parts of the retractor once a month.
Lubricant: Use a high-quality, surgical-grade instrument lubricant; do not use industrial oils.
Application: Ensure the lubricant reaches all moving parts for smooth operation and to prevent seizing.
Storage 
Environment: Store surgical instruments in a dry, clean environment.
Protection: Seal away instruments to prevent exposure to moisture, which can lead to oxidation and rust.
Inspection: Before use, visually inspect the retractor for any signs of corrosion, damage, or wear.

NAME: Internal Mammary Retractor, Reversable with 2 sliding hook
BRIEF: An internal mammary retractor with two reversible, sliding hooks is a specialized surgical instrument used primarily in cardiothoracic surgery to harvest the internal mammary artery (IMA). It is a self-retaining device that allows surgeons to perform procedures like Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) with a clear and stable view of the surgical site
DESCRIPTION:
Application: The primary purpose is to expose the internal mammary artery during cardiac and thoracic procedures. It works by gently lifting and retracting the chest wall and sternum.
Self-retaining mechanism: A screw-driven or ratcheted mechanism holds the retractor in position, providing continuous tension without requiring a surgeon's hands to hold it throughout the procedure.
Reversible, sliding hooks: The hooks can be repositioned and reversed to provide optimal access and exposure, depending on the anatomical needs of the patient. They are inserted under the sternum to lift and retract the rib cage.
Construction: The tool is made from high-grade surgical stainless steel, ensuring its durability, resistance to corrosion, and suitability for repeated sterilization.
Ergonomics: The design provides stable retraction and frees the surgeon's hands, which improves efficiency during delicate procedures.
USAGE:
Placement: The hooks of the retractor are carefully placed under the sternum on either side.
Expansion: The surgeon uses a screw-driven or ratcheted mechanism to expand the retractor. This gently lifts the chest wall and spreads the ribs.
Adjustment: The sliding, reversible hooks can be independently adjusted along a horizontal bar to customize the retraction for the specific patient and surgical requirements.
Harvesting: With the chest wall safely and steadily retracted, the surgeon has clear access to harvest the internal mammary artery for use in a bypass graft.
